Message.Title: Lenovo and Windows 8 to dominate China & USA in all mobile sales
Message.Msg: Lenovo has a good cash position within declining PC sector Lenovo’s results for fiscal 2012-13 showed earnings of $635 million, up 34% year-over-year, and full year EPS of $6.16. The company had 52.4 million PC shipments and holds 15.5% global market share. Lenovo is focused on transforming itself into a “PC Plus Leader” by adding tablets and smartphones to its core PC business. As of March 31, it had net cash reserves of $3.1 billion, which decreased 25% from 2012. The company asserts it has a very liquid position, and during the previous fiscal year drew $300 million from a five-year loan facility agreement that was entered into in July 2009. It has another $500 million loan facility agreement that hasn’t been used and short-term credit facilities of $6.9 million. Bank borrowings increased 179% to $176 million due to Lenovo’s acquisition of CCE, a consumer technology company in Brazil.

I expect it will be trading over $50 by end of the year (perhaps primed for a 2:1 split when it reaches $80 12 months from now!!).

Message.Title: Microsoft Q4 Earnings: A Surfeit of Surfaces and the Post-PC Era = Trouble
Message.Msg: Google it. Quoting: "Microsoft had a bad fourth quarter, mostly because many people are not using PCs any more. In addition, the tech giant took a $900 million charge related to having to cut the price of its Surface RT tablet, which had — as you might imagine — an impact on results. "Missed profit expectations, missed revenue, missed all over the ying-yang. "Now, a conference call to explain it all to you by new Microsoft CFO Amy Hood. She has just gotten the job and now has to put a good face on a bad situation, as well as to give more details of the software giant’s recent restructuring of its business. "2:31 pm: I simply do not envy the job of Hood, who has just been handed the ugly task of explaining Microsoft’s weak earnings in the fourth quarter. "Essentially, despite longtime protests to the contrary, Microsoft has finally got to admit that the PC era is over, after years of trying not to and employing ever more pretzel-icious euphemisms to include PC in the mix. " “In many ways,” said Hood about the quarterly results, “it reflects the trends.” "Then, miracle of miracles, she actually talked about a PC market decline in an honest way, which the software giant has been loath to do over these many years of, you know, the decline. "Hood could not put any shine on this fact and did not try to. "Windows was declining, she said, and it was time for Microsoft to “evolve beyond the PC” into the “modern era of computing.” "It’s an “incremental process,” said Hood, meaning it’s hard to turn a lumbering battleship around so quickly, even though this torpedo has been headed toward it for quite a while now. "But, she said, “we know we have to do better,” noting that is why the company recently did its massive restructuring to morph into “One Microsoft.” "

Message.Title: MSFT Earnings....
Message.Msg: Folks I just had a chance to listen to the earnings CC and read the transcript.... While the numbers look discouraging, one main factor that has missed the attention of the media is the change in "Revenue Recognition" from outright sale to "Subscription" and that is why we are carrying a "record un-billed revenue of over $24 billion".... This issue was raised by a couple of analysts and the MSFT CFO's comments were that these revenues will be recognized during the next four quarters, or over $6 billion per quarter which otherwise would have put us over the estimates both on the top line and the earnings despite taking nearly $1 billion of write off which will add to revenue as the inventory is sold off during the next couple of quarters.... ALSO being the last quarter for the fiscal year past and the re-organization, the management cleaned the books and took all the charges they could.... However with our Cloud business, XBOX ONE, Windows 8.1 and Best Buy MSFT stores kicking into high gear, the next several quarters will surprise to the upside as the new revenue recognition system kicks into full scale operation.... I expect some selling by traders as the long term investors will be adding on this Dip. Osso

Message.Title: Oversold & Underloved...
Message.Msg: Overall FY results were great. Q4 disappointed, but this company is still immensely profitable. For these shares to get whacked almost 8% because they didn't meet the street's lofty expectations is silly. I think MSFT needs to continue to focus on its' core businesses. Sure it isn't the growth company it once was, but how many large corporations maintain the breakneck growth rates that enabled them to become large corporations...NONE. It is fair to accept that MSFT is a mature company, albeit one with excellent margins and great assets. This stock continues to be oversold & under-loved. The only way for this business to get the fair valuation it deserves is to split it up or return greater sums of cash to its shareholders.

Message.Title: On the surface
Message.Msg: 1. The issue with tablets is not the tablet, but the confusing tablet-laptop. Such hybrids don't work well because of cost. Price is simply the factor that decides iPad vs Surface. Period. No more analysis is needed. 2. Surface Pro is bulkier. Its the gigantic Intel processor demanding more cooling resources. Form factor is very very very very very important. 3. Desktop of Windows 8 is not very touch friendly. It sucks in fact. Trying to zoom in is a horror story. Just doesn't work. I hate it. 4. Either use guns to make money or candy. Apple throws in a lot of candy. Candies wins eventually. Using guns is like falling into the pits of tartarus. You have to keep going in until you die. If you try to come out and rectify the mistake, unless done diligently and with true remorse you'll be killed anyway. Moral of the story, avoid tartarus and guns, unless you are in a battle field. Don't make the civilian into a warrior. 5. Get the right kind of candies. If the wrapper looks good but the chocolates tastes awful, no one's going to buy it. When you copy the skin, you need to copy the meat as well. 6. There are some great original stuff in Microsoft. Emphasize and build on those strengths. 7. Emphasize WIndows RT with real great form factor..... and fix the desktop touch issues (difficult to use).

Message.Title: SURFACE CLONE coming in CHINA & USA (LENOVO & Windows 8)
Message.Msg: Lenovo's Future . Lenovo has a good cash position within declining PC sector Lenovo’s results for fiscal 2012-13 showed earnings of $635 million, up 34% year-over-year, and full year EPS of $6.16. The company had 52.4 million PC shipments and holds 15.5% global market share. Lenovo is focused on transforming itself into a “PC Plus Leader” by adding tablets and smartphones to its core PC business. As of March 31, it had net cash reserves of $3.1 billion, which decreased 25% from 2012. The company asserts it has a very liquid position, and during the previous fiscal year drew $300 million from a five-year loan facility agreement that was entered into in July 2009. It has another $500 million loan facility agreement that hasn’t been used and short-term credit facilities of $6.9 million. Bank borrowings increased 179% to $176 million due to Lenovo’s acquisition of CCE, a consumer technology company in Brazil

Message.Title: Morningstar
Message.Msg: Microsoft MSFT reported weak fourth-quarter results, highlighting the challenges facing its Windows franchise due to the declining fortunes of the PC market. Nevertheless, with our relatively modest expectations and the fact that a large part of the weak results were due to a one-time inventory write-down, we're sticking with our $35-per-share fair value estimate. Although we believe the firm still has a wide Morningstar Economic Moat rating, we highlight our negative moat trend rating.The firm's flagship Windows division suffered from a $900 million write-down for Surface RT inventory, confirming what had long been suspected: RT tablets are selling poorly. On a GAAP basis, Windows revenue grew 6.2% versus the year-ago period as modest commercial sales were offset by abysmal consumer demand. Overall, this was the theme for the quarter, as the other business segments reflected a still solid enterprise business that took share in key markets, while the consumer side of the business remained weak. Quarterly operating income was $26.8 billion, a 5% year-over-year decline due to higher costs of revenue from product mix shift, increased sales and marketing costs, and increased infrastructure expenses. We expect the cost of revenue to continue climbing over time as the firm increases its investments in Windows Azure, Office 365, and hardware products. The weaker operating profit also reflected the $900 million inventory write-down. . Norman Young

Message.Title: Disappointing...But I Remain A Long. Here's Why.
Message.Msg: 10% seems an irrational reaction. MSFT still grew top line revenue and operating profits. Earnings per share are up relative to a year ago. The cash value of the company increased from $120 billion to $142 billion. What pundits are attacking is that Windows revenue declined. Again, I personally feel this does not warrant a 10% haircut. I've owned this stock since 2006 and have a 55% gain as of today, reinvesting dividends. Yesterday it was a %70 gain, something I feel I will see again before the end of the year. Why? Because from what I can tell, Windows fell due to secular economic issues. Nearly every major vendor has hit some bumps: IBM, Oracle, SAP, Google, among others. PC shipments have stalled, but this is not the death of Windows, let alone Microsoft. MSFT is adapting to developing mobile, social, and cloud computing technologies. So are Oracle, IBM, SAP, and Cisco. All these companies remain cash machines, as well as R&D machines. The software companies in particular have a range of applications well suited to the cloud, with the ability to offer 1 stop shopping. Never mind that MSFT is in a diversity of markets on top of this. I remain a long. At a PE = 12, I might buy more. Best of luck to all.

Message.Title: I have news for you Googles decline in cost per click in ads is worse than you think.
Message.Msg: Their sales people have been badgering businesses trying to get them to upgrade the account just so they can make more. I had a sales Person that was calling every few days. I can see what the ads are costing everyone. So Bing ads have affected google cost per click. That is what an advertisor bids to have their ads appear near the top of search rankings. If you have a business try a lower cost per click. Also do not upgrade to their new interface unless you want to pay more. You can check the box that says have your ad appear in other content than google main search or something similar. That will get you maybe 100's of thousands of more displays and your ad still shows the same way in the google main search. I have tested it. I may try and save people money and post the exact method. Just my opinion.

Message.Title: Seeking Alpha: Does Microsoft Get The Message Yet?
Message.Msg: A little snippet.... Anybody who has been reading my posts will know that my disclosures at the top have not included "I am long MSFT." This is because I took my profits some time ago (and admittedly missed the final leg of the run). While I fundamentally believe in the company's engineering prowess, I have a significant problem with its tablet strategy. In the most recent quarter, Microsoft (MSFT) announced that it took a $900M write-down on unsold Surface RT inventory. I warned that Surface RT and, by extension, Windows RT was a flop, and until I see Microsoft "getting" the message, the tablet strategy will still falter. Why Windows RT Is Dangerous As somebody who follows this space, I have noticed that despite Microsoft's asinine attempt to create a version of Windows that is fundamentally crippled for tablets in order to capitalize on ARM (ARMH) hyperbole, Microsoft's own full version of Windows 8 that runs on standard X86 processors has managed to gain significant share in the tablet space. In Q1, Intel (INTC) (the only supplier of X86 chips for this space at the moment) took 90% share of the Windows tablet market, which in turn translated into roughly 6% of the tablet market at large.

Topic.Title: MSFT IS A STEAL AT THIS PRICE

Message.Msg: Short term, you may get a bounce and make money, but long term, this company missed and missed bad. Apple is so far ahead of them on tablets, and people are now comfortable not using Microsoft software on their "device" whatever they're using. Google shot out like a rocket with Droid, and Microsoft stayed with the PC. Now the big thing is "cloud", which Amazon is cutting their prices under MSFT. I think this "cloud" computing is a long-term strategy, but don't you think that the other competitors are going to think bigger as well? Google Docs isn't that bad (even though I use MS Office), and I wouldn't be surprised if Apple doesn't somehow get in the game beyond iTunes content delivery. Just a thought that while this may be a short term winner, and I hope it is for you, but I think long-term, I want to be in a player that's got good thought leadership going forward, and I think MSFT lost its' mojo a while ago.

Message.Title: Microsoft hits skids as Windows questions grow
Message.Msg: Google it. Quoting: ... "Microsoft MSFT -11.40% fell as much as 12.5% during the day — putting it on track for the worst single-day percentage decline for the stock since April 2000 — before recovering slightly to close with a loss of 11.4% at $31.40. It was Microsoft’s lowest close since April. "At least two brokers cut their ratings on the stock, and at least half a dozen have scaled back price targets, according to data from Thomson Reuters. About 62% of the analysts covering Microsoft now rate the shares as neutral, with only 32% holding buy ratings, according to Thomson. "Cowen & Co. and Raymond James cut their ratings on the software giant to the equivalent of neutral, with many more chiming in with negative impressions about the company’s current direction."

Message.Title: As Detroit Wobbles, So Does Microsoft
Message.Msg: Google it. Quoting: "A day of reckoning arrived on Thursday for a once vibrant icon of industry. Separately, Detroit filed for bankruptcy. "It seems almost appropriate that Microsoft delivered one of its worst financial performances in memory on the same day that Detroit became the largest American city to file for bankruptcy protection. For years, people have noted parallels between the decline of the auto industry and the maturing of the PC business, comparisons that have become more credible as evidence accumulates of a shift to a post-PC era. "The parallels aren’t diminished by the fact that Steve Ballmer, Microsoft’s chief executive, is a Detroit native, whose father was a longtime Ford manager, and that Mr. Ballmer has sought the counsel of Alan Mulally, Ford’s chief executive, on Microsoft management issues."
